intro: Maihueniopsis pentlandii, commonly known as the Patagonian sunflower, is a flowering plant native to the Andes and Patagonia regions of South America. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and robust, hairy stems. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to the harsh climate of its native habitat. Its yellow flowers bloom in late summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its unique adaptations and limited distribution, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
